articles.headline: A New Route to the Toy Chest
articles.snippet: The popular toy company is creating a direct-to-consumer program to sell the Wooden Railway line of Thomas products, via catalogs and a new website.
articles.abstract: The popular toy company is creating a direct-to-consumer program to sell the Wooden Railway line of Thomas products, via catalogs and a new website.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like many 4-year-olds, Benny Nelson adores Thomas the Tank Engine.

articles.headline: Taking a Broker to Arbitration
articles.snippet: The regulatory organization that oversees Wall Street is considering how to improve arbitration’s transparency, impartiality and efficiency.
articles.abstract: The regulatory organization that oversees Wall Street is considering how to improve arbitration’s transparency, impartiality and efficiency.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you have a problem with your investment broker and you cannot resolve the dispute on your own, you probably won’t get your day in court. But you will be heard, most likely in a conference room somewhere, before a panel of arbitrators.

articles.headline: Part-Time Schedules, Full-Time Headaches
articles.snippet: New York Times readers responded to an article published Wednesday about part-time and on-call work with their own experiences.
articles.abstract: New York Times readers responded to an article published Wednesday about part-time and on-call work with their own experiences.
articles.lead_paragraph: A worker at an apparel store at Woodbury Common, an outlet mall north of New York City, said that even though some part-time employees clamored for more hours, the store had hired more part-timers and cut many workers’ hours to 10 a week from 20.

articles.headline: General Motors Resists Expanding Victims’ Fund
articles.snippet: The company maintains that a distinct difference exists between its recall of 2.6 million older Chevrolet Cobalts and other cars, and has refused to expand a compensation fund, infuriating safety advocates.
articles.abstract: The company maintains that a distinct difference exists between its recall of 2.6 million older Chevrolet Cobalts and other cars, and has refused to expand a compensation fund, infuriating safety advocates.
articles.lead_paragraph: The cars are different, but the circumstances surrounding their recall are strikingly similar.
articles.byline: By Danielle Ivory and Rebecca R. Ruiz

articles.headline: Next Gold Rush: Legal Marijuana Feeds Entrepreneurs’ Dreams
articles.snippet: Many investors and job-seekers are flocking to Washington and Colorado to take advantage of the legal marijuana industry, but the risks can be high and the rewards nonexistent.
articles.abstract: Many investors and job-seekers are flocking to Washington and Colorado to take advantage of the legal marijuana industry, but the risks can be high and the rewards nonexistent.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENVER — Like the glint of gold or rumors of oil in ages past, the advent of legal, recreational marijuana is beginning to reshape economies in Colorado and Washington State.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy and Kirk Johnson

articles.headline: For the G.O.P., Fine Line Seen on Migration
articles.snippet: The recent wave of young migrants has complicated the Republican Party’s effort to win back the support of Latinos while gaining immigration reform.
articles.abstract: The recent wave of young migrants has complicated the Republican Party’s effort to win back the support of Latinos while gaining immigration reform.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In 1996, when a surge in illegal immigration collided with the overheated politics of a presidential election, Republicans demanded a strict crackdown.

articles.headline: Rebels in Ukraine Crowed of Past Attacks, but Deny This One
articles.snippet: As investigators look into who shot down a Malaysia Airlines jet, the rebels in Ukraine have been using increasingly powerful weapons against hard-to-reach targets.
articles.abstract: As investigators look into who shot down a Malaysia Airlines jet, the rebels in Ukraine have been using increasingly powerful weapons against hard-to-reach targets.
articles.lead_paragraph: GRABOVO, Ukraine — A blast from a shoulder-fired rocket takes down a Ukrainian military transport plane on its landing approach, killing 49 people. Twenty-three Ukrainian soldiers are slaughtered by Russian-made Grad rockets. An AN-26 military plane is shot down at 21,000 feet, an altitude reachable only by a sophisticated surface-to-air missile with radar guidance.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: Your Rights, Buried in Paperwork
articles.snippet: Dell shareholders want an appraisal of the founder’s takeover bid for the company. But he wants documents, lots of them.
articles.abstract: Dell shareholders want an appraisal of the founder’s takeover bid for the company. But he wants documents, lots of them.
articles.lead_paragraph: When shareholders receive takeover bids for their companies, they may feel like celebrating. But what if the buyout price doesn’t fully reflect a fair value for the company?

articles.headline: A Family Feud, Uncorked in Spain
articles.snippet: Vega Sicilia’s wine is triumphant, but its ruling clan’s bickering has been leaving a sour taste.
articles.abstract: Vega Sicilia’s wine is triumphant, but its ruling clan’s bickering has been leaving a sour taste.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Pablo Álvarez began sending invitations to a recent 150th anniversary party for Vega Sicilia, the historic winery he runs in the Ribera del Duero region of Spain, he offered one to his estranged father, David Álvarez, who bought the winery in 1982. The party was sure to be a blowout, with 700 guests — including Soraya Sáenz de Santamaría, the deputy prime minister of Spain, along with fans of the winery like Kurt Russell, Goldie Hawn and Kate Hudson — and with food provided by El Celler de Can Roca, a restaurant in Catalonia that is considered one of the world’s best.

articles.headline: In a Subprime Bubble for Used Cars, Borrowers Pay Sky-High Rates
articles.snippet: Millions of Americans are receiving auto loans they cannot possibly afford, in a lending climate marked by some of the same lack of caution seen in the housing industry before its 2008 implosion.
articles.abstract: Millions of Americans are receiving auto loans they cannot possibly afford, in a lending climate marked by some of the same lack of caution seen in the housing industry before its 2008 implosion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rodney Durham stopped working in 1991, declared bankruptcy and lives on Social Security. Nonetheless, Wells Fargo lent him $15,197 to buy a used Mitsubishi sedan.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Michael Corkery

articles.headline: With Jet Strike, War in Ukraine Is Felt Globally
articles.snippet: The downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 rippled across multiple continents, bringing home in vivid relief the consequences of a struggle that had seemed far removed for many.
articles.abstract: The downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 rippled across multiple continents, bringing home in vivid relief the consequences of a struggle that had seemed far removed for many.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — From the start, the telephone call did not go well. Dispensing with pleasantries, President Vladimir V. Putin launched into an edgy and long-winded complaint about the new American sanctions imposed on Russia the day before.

articles.headline: Rush to Deport Young Migrants Could Trample Asylum Claims
articles.snippet: Young migrants from Central American countries have stories of abuse, abandonment and flight from organized crime that could make them eligible for U.S. entry, but they are often not heard.
articles.abstract: Young migrants from Central American countries have stories of abuse, abandonment and flight from organized crime that could make them eligible for U.S. entry, but they are often not heard.
articles.lead_paragraph: HARLINGEN, Tex. — The first time her aunt in Mexico took her out at night, the young teenager was told they were headed to a party.

articles.headline: Frack Quietly, Please: Sage Grouse Is Nesting
articles.snippet: The greater sage grouse might be declared an endangered species, restricting development of its habitat, leading the energy industry and the government to try to save the bird.
articles.abstract: The greater sage grouse might be declared an endangered species, restricting development of its habitat, leading the energy industry and the government to try to save the bird.
articles.lead_paragraph: CASPER, Wyo. — In a new oil field among the rolling hills near here, Chesapeake Energy limits truck traffic to avoid disturbing the breeding and nesting of a finicky bird called the greater sage grouse. To the west, on a gas field near Yellowstone National Park, Shell Oil is sowing its own special seed mix to grow plants that nourish the birds and hide their chicks from predators.
articles.byline: By Diane Cardwell and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Shake-Up on Opium Island
articles.snippet: Tasmania, with its huge poppy crop, is the top producer of a crucial raw material in prescription drugs. But companies fear that they depend too much on that harvest.
articles.abstract: Tasmania, with its huge poppy crop, is the top producer of a crucial raw material in prescription drugs. But companies fear that they depend too much on that harvest.
articles.lead_paragraph: Now is the sowing season for opium poppies in the Australian state of Tasmania. Tractors chug up and down paddocks, pulling elaborate machinery that drills pairs of adjacent, miniature holes in the dirt, and then drops a dozen tiny kernels of fertilizer in one of the holes and a tiny poppy seed in the other.

articles.headline: Neighborhood Ravaged on Deadliest Day So Far for Both Sides in Gaza
articles.snippet: The withering assault on the neighborhood of Shejaiya, and the death of 87 Palestinians and 13 Israeli soldiers and officers, appeared to shake the international community.
articles.abstract: The withering assault on the neighborhood of Shejaiya, and the death of 87 Palestinians and 13 Israeli soldiers and officers, appeared to shake the international community.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY — The mayhem began in the early hours of Sunday morning in Shejaiya, an eastern neighborhood of Gaza City, where Israeli forces battled with Hamas militants. Terrified civilians fled, sometimes past the bodies of those struck down in earlier artillery barrages. By dusk it was clear that Sunday was the deadliest single day for the Palestinians in the latest conflict and the deadliest for the Israeli military in years.
articles.byline: By Anne Barnard and Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: Bodies From Malaysia Airlines Flight Are Stuck in Ukraine, Held Hostage Over Distrust
articles.snippet: World leaders expressed a growing outrage over pro-Russian rebels’ refusal to cede authority over the site where the downed jet’s debris is scattered.
articles.abstract: World leaders expressed a growing outrage over pro-Russian rebels’ refusal to cede authority over the site where the downed jet’s debris is scattered.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOREZ, Ukraine — Three wrenching days after the downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17, the bodies of most of those aboard have ended up here, in a fly-infested railway station in a rough coal-mining town in eastern Ukraine.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise and Noah Sneider

articles.headline: In Gaza, Epithets Are Fired and Euphemisms Give Shelter
articles.snippet: In a clash of narratives, officials from both Israel and Gaza advise supporters on the language and images that should be used on social media platforms.
articles.abstract: In a clash of narratives, officials from both Israel and Gaza advise supporters on the language and images that should be used on social media platforms.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Gaza-based interior ministry advises its supporters in a YouTube video that whenever talking about the dead, “always add ‘an innocent citizen.’ ” In Israel, the message is quite different: Those same victims are described as “human shields” sacrificed by the “heartless” Hamas “terrorists” that rule Gaza.

articles.headline: Alibaba’s I.P.O. Could Be a Bonanza for the Scions of Chinese Leaders
articles.snippet: An intricate web of shell companies disclosed in filings by Alibaba connects the company to the sons and grandsons of the most powerful men in China.
articles.abstract: An intricate web of shell companies disclosed in filings by Alibaba connects the company to the sons and grandsons of the most powerful men in China.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was billed as the biggest private financing deal in the history of China.

articles.headline: Smaller Cable Networks Plan Their Survival Under the Feet of Giants
articles.snippet: Faced with a worrisome loss in negotiating power, lesser players like AMC and Discovery Communications are seeking ways to secure their own relevance.
articles.abstract: Faced with a worrisome loss in negotiating power, lesser players like AMC and Discovery Communications are seeking ways to secure their own relevance.
articles.lead_paragraph: The flesh-eating zombies in AMC’s hit television series “The Walking Dead” are shambling into a land of even bigger monsters.
articles.byline: By Emily Steel and David Gelles

articles.headline: Missouri Alone in Resisting Prescription Drug Database
articles.snippet: In declining to keep a prescription drug database, the state has hampered its ability to combat abuse and also drawn buyers from neighboring states.
articles.abstract: In declining to keep a prescription drug database, the state has hampered its ability to combat abuse and also drawn buyers from neighboring states.
articles.lead_paragraph: SIKESTON, Mo. — On his office phone at L & S Pharmacy, Richard Logan listened as a doctor’s office detailed how a patient had just left with her third prescription for painkillers in only nine days — and was quite possibly getting more, illegally, elsewhere.

articles.headline: Microsoft’s Top Lawyer Is the Tech World’s Envoy
articles.snippet: Bradford L. Smith, general counsel at the tech company, uses the skills he learned as a Washington lawyer to advocate change in government policies that affect the industry.
articles.abstract: Bradford L. Smith, general counsel at the tech company, uses the skills he learned as a Washington lawyer to advocate change in government policies that affect the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: REDMOND, Wash. — Bradford L. Smith, Microsoft’s general counsel, was in Berlin meeting with government officials this spring when a case kept popping up unexpectedly.

articles.headline: Africans Open Fuller Wallets to the Future
articles.snippet: Across sub-Saharan Africa, consumer demand is fueling the continent’s economies in new ways, driving hopes that Africa will emerge as a success story.
articles.abstract: Across sub-Saharan Africa, consumer demand is fueling the continent’s economies in new ways, driving hopes that Africa will emerge as a success story.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — Across sub-Saharan Africa, consumer demand is fueling the continent’s economies in new ways, driving hopes that Africa will emerge as a success story in the coming years comparable to the rise of the East Asian Tigers in the second half of the 20th century.

articles.headline: Riding the Juggernaut That Left Print Behind
articles.snippet: To the extent that 21st Century Fox’s unrequited bid for Time Warner Inc. offered a crystal ball on the future of media, print doesn’t seem as if it will be much a part of it.
articles.abstract: To the extent that 21st Century Fox’s unrequited bid for Time Warner Inc. offered a crystal ball on the future of media, print doesn’t seem as if it will be much a part of it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even if you aren’t one of those people worried about media consolidation — there are many in that number — the big bolt of lightning last week that pierced a summer of ennui in entertainment and publishing news was hard to resist.

articles.headline: A Tough Corporate Job Asks One Question: Can You Hack It?
articles.snippet: To combat the growing threat of online breaches, companies and governments are hiring chief information security officers — whose main responsibility is to make sure data systems are secure.
articles.abstract: To combat the growing threat of online breaches, companies and governments are hiring chief information security officers — whose main responsibility is to make sure data systems are secure.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Pity the poor chief information security officer.

articles.headline: Russia’s Message on Jet: Conciliation and Bluster
articles.snippet: President Vladimir V. Putin seems to be probing for a way out of the crisis of the downed Malaysia Airlines jet without appearing to compromise with the West.
articles.abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin seems to be probing for a way out of the crisis of the downed Malaysia Airlines jet without appearing to compromise with the West.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia presented a combination of conciliation and bluster on Monday over its handling of the downed Malaysia Airlines jet, with President Vladimir V. Putin seemingly probing for a way out of the crisis without appearing to compromise with the West.

articles.headline: Israel Is Facing Difficult Choice in Gaza Conflict
articles.snippet: With the lopsided casualty count mounting, world leaders are demanding a halt to the hostilities. But Israel’s ground invasion operation has uncovered more militants’ tunnels than it expected.
articles.abstract: With the lopsided casualty count mounting, world leaders are demanding a halt to the hostilities. But Israel’s ground invasion operation has uncovered more militants’ tunnels than it expected.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israeli leaders have stressed two points in selling their Gaza Strip ground invasion internationally and at home: that they embraced all cease-fire proposals and that troops are targeting tunnels used by Palestinian militants to infiltrate their territory.
